item.title: [EMCpp]Item-40 Use std::atomic for Concurrency, volatile for Special Memory
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: std::atomic is for data accessed from multiple threads without using mutexes (concurrent usage); volatile is for memory where reads and writes should not be optimised away (special memory).
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-39 Consider Void Futures for One-Shot Event Communication
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Using std::promises and futures is useful skill to create one-shot communication between a detecting task and reacting task.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-38 Be Aware of Varying Thread Handle Destructor Behavior
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Future destructors normally just destroy the future’s data members, execept for the final future referring to a shared state for a non-deferred task launched via std::async, which blocks until the task completes.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-37 Make std::threads Unjoinable on All Paths
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Join-on-destruction can lead to difficult-to-debug performance anomalies; while detach-on-destruction can lead to difficult-to-debug undefined behavior.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-36 Specify std::launch::async if Asynchronicity Is Essential
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The flexibility that default policy for std::async permits both async and sync task execution leads to uncertainty when accessing thread_locals, implies that the task may never execute, and affects program logic for timeout-based wait calls.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-35 Prefer Task-Based Programming to Thread-Based
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Thread-based programming calls for manual management of thread exhaustion, oversubscription, load balancing, and adaptation to new platforms, while task-based programming via std::async with the default launch policy handles most of the issues for us.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-34 Prefer Lambdas to std::bind
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Lambdas are more readable, more expressive, and may be more efficient than using std::bind.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-33 Use decltype on auto&& parameters to std::forward them
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: C++14 introduces generic lambdas, which use auto in their parameter specifications.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-32 Use Init Capture to Move Objects Into Closures
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Use init capture to move objects into closures in C++14; emulate init capture via hand-written classes or std::bind in C++11.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-31 Avoid Default Capture Modes
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Default by-reference capture can lead to dangling references; default by-value capture is susceptible to dangling pointers, while misleadingly susggests the lambdas are self-contained.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-30 Failure Cases in Perfect Forwarding
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Perfect forwarding fails when template type deduction fails or when it deduces the wrong type.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-29 Assume Move Operations Are Not Present Not Cheap, and Not Used
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: There are several scenarios in which C++11’s move semantics do us no good:
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-28 Understand Reference Collapsing
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Reference collapsing occurs in four contexts: template instantiation, auto type generation, creation and use of typedefs and alias declarations, and decltype.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-27 Alternatives to Overloading on Universal References
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Universal reference parameters often have efficiency advantages, but they typically have usability disadvantages.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-26 Avoid Overloading on Universal References
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Overloading on universal references almost always leads to the universal reference overload being called more frequently than expected.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-25 Use std::move on Rvalue References, std::forward on Universal References
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: But don’t apply std::move or std::forward to local objects if they would otherwise be eligible for the return value optimization.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-24 Distinguish Universal References From Rvalue References
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: If a function template parameter has type T&& for a deduced type T, or if an object is declared using auto&&, the parameter or object is a universal reference.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-23 Understand std::Move and std::Forward
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: std::move performs an unconditional cast to an rvalue, while std::forward casts its argument to an rvalue only if that argument is bound to an rvalue.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-22 When Using Pimple Idiom, Define Special Member Functions in the Implementation File
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: For std::unique_ptr pImpl pointers, declare special member functions in the class header, but implement them in the implementation file.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-21 Prefer std::make_unique and std::make_shared to Direct Use of New
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Compared to new, make functions eliminate source code duplication, improve exception safety, and, for std::make_shard and std::allocate_shared, generate code that’s smaller and faster.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-20 Use Weak_ptr for Shared_ptr Like Pointers That Can Dangle
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Potential use cases for std::weak_ptr include caching, observer lists, and the prevention of std::shared_ptr cycles.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-19 Use std::Shared_ptr for Shared-ownership Resource Management
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: std::shared_ptrs offer convenience approaching that of garbage collection for the shared lifetime management of arbitrary resources.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-18 Use std::unique_ptr for Exclusive-ownership Resource Management
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: std::unique_ptr is a small, fast, move-only smart pointer for managing resources with exclusive-ownership semantics.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-17 Understand Special Member Function Generation
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The special member functions are those ccompilers may generate on their own: default constructor, destructor, copy operations, and move operations.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-16 Make Const Member Functions Thread Safe
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Make const member functions thread safe unless we’re certain they’ll never be used in a concurrent context.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-15 Use Constexpr Whenever Possible
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: constexpr objects are const and are initialized with values known during compilation; constexpr functions can produce copmile-time results when called with arguments whose values are know during compilations.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-14 Declare Functions Noexcept if They Won't Emit Exception
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Most functions are exception-neutral, but for some, such as move operations, swap, memory deallocation functions, and destructors, noexcept is particularly valuable.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-13 Prefer Const_iterators to Iterators
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: In maximally generic code, prefer non-member versions of begin, end, rbegin, etc., over their member function counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-12 Declare Overriding Functions Override
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: C++11 gives us a way to make explicit that a derived class function is supposed to override a base class version: override.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Nodes on Clean Architecture
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: A brief notes on Clean Architecture
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-11 Prefer Deleted Functions to Private Undefined Ones
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Any function may be deleted, including non-member functions and template instantiations.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-10 Prefer Scoped enums to Unscopded enums
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Enumerators of scoped enums are visible only within the enum, convert to other types only with a cast, and always support forward-declared because their default underlying type is int.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-9 Prefer Alias Declarations to Typedefs
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Alias declaration support templatization, which avoids the “::type” suffix and “typename” prefix often required to refer typedefs.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-8 Prefer Nullptr to 0 and NULL
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: nullptr doean’t suffer from the overloading problem or the template deduction problem that 0 and NULL are susceptible to. It also improves code clarity.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-7 Distinguish Betwenn () and {} When Creating Objects
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Braced initialization is the most widely usable initialization syntax, which can also prevent narrowing conversions, as well as being immune to C++'s most vexing parse.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-6 Use the Explicitly Typed Initializer Idiom when auto deduces undesired types
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: “Invisible” proxy types can cause auto to deduce the undesired type for an initializing expression, so we can adopt explicitly typed initializer idiom to force auto to deduce what we want.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-5 Prefer Auto to Explicit Type Declarations
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Despite some pitfalls described in EMCpp item 2 and 6, auto variables are preferred for they must be initialized, are generally immune to type mismatches that can lead to portability or efficiency problems, can ease the process of refactoring, and typically require less typing than variables with explicitly specified types.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-4 Know How to View Deduced Types
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Deduced types can often be seen using IDE editors, compiler error messages, and the Boost TypeIndex library, but the results of some tools may be neither helpful nor accurate.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-3 Understand Decltype
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: decltype almost always yields the type of a variable or expression without any modifications. For lvalue expressions of type T other than names, decltype always reports a type of T&.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-2 Understand Auto Type Deduction
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: auto type deduction is usually the same as template type deduction, with an exception in the case of braced initializer. Also, in C++14, as a function return type or a lambda parameter, auto implies template type deduction instead of auto type deduction.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [EMCpp]Item-1 Understand Template Type Deduction
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: There are three sets of rules for type deduction in modern C++: one for function templates, one for auto, and one for decltype. Without a solid understanding of how deduction operates, effective programming in modern C++ is all but impossible.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: A Brief Review of Dynamo
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: As a highly available and scalable distributed data store, the design principles of Dynamo features high availability for writes (via reconciliation during reads), incremental scalability (consistent hashing), symmetry, decentralization, and heterogeneity (via virtual nodes).
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: A simple archive for music generation
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: A random collection of recent works on music generation.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-34 Understand How to Combine C++ and C in the Same Program
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: There are five points worth noting if we want to mix C++ and C in the same program.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-33 Make Non-Leaf Classes Abstract
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The general rule: non-leaf classes should be abstract. This will yields dividends in the form of increased reliability, robustness, comprehensibility, and extensibility throughout our software.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-32 Program in the Future Tense
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Things change. Future tense thinking increases the reusability of the code we write, enhances its maintainability, makes it more robust, and facilitates gracefully in an environment where change is a certainty.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-31 Making Functions Virtual With Respect to More Than One Object
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: A virtual function call is termed a “message dispatch.” A call that acts virtual on multiple parameters is called multiple dispatch, which is not directly supported in C++. Several resolutions exist, but none is without its disadvantages.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-30 Proxy Classes
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Objects that stand for other objects are often called proxy objects (or surrogates), and the classes that give rise to proxy objects are often called proxy classes, which is useful for implementing multidimensional arrays, differentiating lvalue/rvalue, and suppressing implicit conversions.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-29 Reference Counting
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Reference counting is technique that allows multiple objects with the same value to share a sinple representation of that value.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-28 Smart Pointers
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Smart pointers are designed to look, act, and feel like built-in pointers, but to offer greater functionality.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-27 Requiring or Prohibiting Heap Based Objects
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Techniques for requiring or prohibiting heap-based objects
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-26 Limiting the Number of Objects of a Class
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Combining object-counting technique with the pseudo-constructors, we can limit the number of objects of a class.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-25 Virtualizing Constructors and Non-Member Functions
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Depending on the different input or dynamic types of function parameters, “virtualization” is a useful technique to construct new objects of different types accordingly, or to conceive of non-member functions whose behavior changes accordingly.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-24 Understand the Costs of Virtual Functions, Multiple Inheritance, Virtual Base Classes, and RTTI
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: It’s important to have a basic understanding of the cost of some C++ features that can have a noticeable impact on the size of objects and the speed at which member functions execute.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-23 Consider Alternative Libraries
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Different libraries offering similar functionality often feature different performance trade-offs, so we might be able to remove bottlenecks by replacing one library with another.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-22 Consider Using op= Instead of Stand Alone op
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Assignment versions of operators (such as operator+=) tend to be more efficient than stand-alone versions of those operators (e.g., operator+).
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-21 Overload to Avoid Implicit Type Conventions
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Overloading to avoid temporaries.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-20 Facilitate the Return Value Optimization
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Take use of the return value optimization in compilers.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-19 Understand the Origin of Temporary Objects
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Unnamed non-heap objects are invisible temporary objects in C++.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-18 Amortize the Cost of Expected Computations
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The old Computer Science story: trade space for time1.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-17 Consider Using Lazy Evaluation
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The best computations are those we never perform at all.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-16 Remember 80-20 Rule
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The 80-20 rule states that 80 percent of a program’s resources are used by about 20 percent of the code.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-15 Understand the Costs of Exception Handling
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Exception handling has costs, and we pay at least some of them even if we never use the keywords try, throw, or catch.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-14 Use Exception Specifications Judiciously
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Exception specifications provide a documentation aid and an enforcement mechanism for constraints on exception usage, but they are only partly checked by compilers and they are easy to violate inadvertently.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-13 Catch Exceptions by Reference
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: If catching by reference, we sidestep the questions about object deletion, avoid slicing exception objects, retain the ability to catch standard exceptions, and limit the number of times exception objects being copied.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-12 Understand How Throwing an Exception Differs From Passing a Parameter or Calling a Virtual Function
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: There are three primary ways in which passing an object to a function or using that object to invoke a virtual function differs from throwing the object as an exception.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-11 Prevent Exceptions From Leaving Destructors
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Keep exceptions from propagating out of destructors to prevent C++ calling terminate during the statck-unwinding part of exception propagation and ensure that every neccessary cleanup is accomplished.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-10 Prevent Resource Leaks in Constructors
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Replace pointer class members with their corresponding smart pointer objects to fortify the constructors against resource leaks in the presence of exceptions, to eliminate the need to manually deallocate resources in destructors, and to allow const member pointers to be handled in the smae graceful fashion as non-const pointers.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-9 Use Destructors to Prevent Resource Leaks
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: To avoid resource leaks in the presence of exceptions, we can encapsulate resources inside objects.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-8 Understand the Different Meanings of New and Delete
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The behaviors of new operator and operator new is different.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-7 Never Overload '&&', '||', or ','
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: If we don’t have a good reason for overloading an operator, don’t overload it. In the case of &&, ||, and ,, it’s difficult to have a good reason: we can’t make them behave the way they’re supposed to.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-6 Distinguish Between Prefix and Postfix Forms of Increment and Decrement Operators
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: The prefix and postfix forms of increment and decrement operators return different types: prefix forms return a reference, while postfix forms return a const object. For efficiency, prefer prefix forms unless the behavior of postfix ones is necessary. To guarantee consistency, implement postfix operators in terms of the prefix operators.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-5 Be Wary of User Defined Conversion Functions
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Implicit type conversions usually lead to more harm than good, so don’t provide conversion functions unless we’re sure we want them.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-4 Avoid Gratuitous Default Constructors
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Including meaningless default constructors affects the efficiency of classes, so avoiding them in classes guarantees fully-initialized objects, with the cost of some limits on how such classes can be used.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-3 Never Treat Arrays Polymorphically
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Array operations almost always involve pointer arithmetic, so arrays and polymorphism don’t mix.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: [MECpp]Item-1 Distinguish Between Pointers and References
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: More effective C++: Use references when we already have something to refer to and never want to refer to anything else, or when implementing operators whose syntactic requires us to do so.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-52 Write placement delete if you write placement new
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: When we write a placement version of operator new, be sure to write the corresponding placement version of operator delete to avoid subtle, intermittent memory leaks. When we do so, pay attention not to unintentionally hide the normal versions of new and delete
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-51 Adhere to convention when writing new and delete
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: operator new should contain an infinite loop trying to allocate memory, should call the new-handler if it can’t satisfy a memory request, and should handle requests for zero bytes; class-specific versions should handle requests for larger blocks than expected. operator delete should do nothing if passed a pointer that is null; class specific versions should handle blocks that are larger than expected.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-50 Understand when it makes sense to replace new and delete
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: There are many valid reasons for writing custom versions of new and delete, including improving performance, debugging heap usage errors, and collecting heap usage information.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-49 Understand the behavior of the new handler
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: set-new-handler allows you to specify a function to be called when memory allocation requests cannot be satisfied.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-48 Be aware of template metaprogramming
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Template metaprogramming can shift work from runtime to compile-time (thus enabling earlier error dettection and higher runtime performance), can be used to generate custom code based on combinations of policy choices, and can also be used to avoid generating code inappropriate for particular types.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-47 Use traits classes for information about types
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Implemented by templates and template specializations, traits classes make information about types available during compilation. Combining traints with overloading, it is possible to perform compile-time if...else tests on types.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-46 Define non-member function inside templates when type conversions are desired
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: When writing a class template that offers functions related to the template that support implicit type conversions on all parameters, define those functions as friends inside the class template.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-45 Use member function templates to accept all compatible types
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: In order to implicitly convert all compatible types for a template class, we neet not a constructor function but a constructor template - member functoin templates that generate member functions of a class.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-44 Factor parameter-independent code out of templates
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Templates generate multiple classes and multiple functions, so any template code not dependent on a template parameter (either non-type template parameters or type parameters) causes bloat: eliminate bloat due to non-type template parameters by replacing template parameters with function parameters or class data members; reduce bloat caused from type parameters by sharing implementations for instantiation types with identical binary representations.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-43 Know how to access names in templatized base classes
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: In derived class templates, refer to names in base class templates via a this-> prefix, via using declarations, or via an explicit base class qualification.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-42 Understand the two meanings of typename
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: When declaring template parameters, both class and typename are interchangeable. When identifying nested dependent type names, use typename, except in base class lists or as a base class identifier in a member initialization list.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-41 Understand inplicit interfaces and compile time polymorphism
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Classes support explicit interfaces based on function signatures, as well as runtime polymorphism through virtual functions; templates support implicit interfaces based on valid expressions, as well as compile-time polymorphism through template instantiation and function overloading resolution.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-40 Use multiple inheritance judiciously
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Being more complex than single inheritance, Multiple inheritance (MI) can lead to ambiguity issues and to the need for virtual inheritance, the latter of which imposes costs in size, speed, and complexity of initialization and assignment, so it’s more practical to make “empty” virtual base classes.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-39 Use private inheritance judiciously
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Private inheritance means is-implemented-in-terms-of. It is usually inferior to composition, but it makes sense when a derived class needs access to protected base members or needs to redefine inherited virtual functions. For library developers who strive to minimize object sizes, it also offers the ability of empty base optimization.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-38 Model 'has-a' or 'is-implemented-in-terms-of' through composition
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: In the application domain, composition means has-a. In the implementation domain, it means is-implemented-in-terms-of.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-37 Never redefine a function's inherited default parameter value
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Defaul parameter values are statically bound, while virtual function - the only functions we should be overriding - are dynamically bound.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-36 Never redefine an inherited non-virtaul function
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: A generalized basic rule from item 7.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-35 Consider Alternatives to Virtual Functions
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Alternatives to virtual functions include the NVI idiom (as an example of the Template Method design pattern) and various forms of the Strategy design pattern.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-34 Differentiate between inheritance of interface and inheritance of implementation
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Inheritance of interface is different from inheritance of implementatino.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-33 Avoid hiding inherited names
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Names in derived classes hide names in base classes, which is not desirable in public inheritance. To fix it, employ using declarations or forwarding functions to make hidden names visible again.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-32 Make sure public inheritance models "Is-A"
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Everything that applies to base classes must also apply to derived classes in public inheritance, for every derived class object is a base class object.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-31 Minimize compilation dependencies between files
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: To minimize compilation dependencies, depend on declarations instead of definitions via techniques such as Handle classes and Interface classes.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-30 Understand ins and outs of inlining
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Limit most inlining to small, frequently called functions to facilitate debugging and binary upgradability, minimize potential code bloat, and maximize the chances of greater program speed.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-29 Strive for exception-safe code
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Exception-safe functions leak no resources and allow no data structures to become corrupted, even when exceptions are thrown. Such functions offer the basic, strong, and nothrow guarantees.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-28 Avoid returning handles to object internals
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Avoid returning handles to object internals to increase encapsulation, help const member functions act const, and minimize the creation of dangling handles.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-27 Minimize_casting
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Avoid casts and develop a cast-free alternative whenever practical, especially dynamic_cast in performance-sensitive code.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-26 Postpone variable definitions as long as possible
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Postponing variable definitions as long as possible increases program clarity and improves progranm efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-25 Consider support for a non-throwing swap
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: When std::swap would be inefficient for your type,provide a non-throwing swap member function, a non-member swap calling the member, and possibly a specialized std::swap for the case of classes (not templates).
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-24 Declare non-member functions when type conversions should apply to all parameters
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: If we need type conversions on all parameters to a function including the one pointed to by the this pointer, the function must be a non-member.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-23 Prefer non-member non-friend function to member function
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Prefer non-member non-friend functions to member functions for better encapsulation, packaging flexibility, and functional extensibility.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-22 Declare data members private
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Declaring data members private gives clients syntactically uniform access to data, affords fine-grained access control, allows invariants to be enforced, and offers class authors implementation flexibility.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-21 Don't return a reference when we have to return an object
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Never return a pointer or reference to a local stack object, a refenrence to a heap-allocated object, or a pointer or reference to a local static object if there is a change that more than one such object will be needed (item 4 provides a “counter” example that is reasonable in single-threaded environments).
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-20 Perfer pass-by-reference-to-const to pass-by-value
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Pass by reference-to-const is typically more efficient than pass by value and avoids the slicing problem.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-19 Treat class design as type design
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Before definining a new type, be sure to consider all the issues discussed in this item.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-18 Make interfaces easy to use correctly and hard to use incorrectly
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Good interfaces are easy to use correctly and hard to use incorrectly.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-17 Store newed objects in smart pointers in standalone statements
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Failure to do this can lead to subtle resource leaks when exceptions are thrown.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-16 Use the same form in corresponding uses of new and delete
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: If you use [] in a new expression, use [] in the corresponding delete expression; If not, no [] in the matching delete expression.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-15 Provide access to raw resource in resource-managing classes
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Each RAII class should offer a way to get at the resource it manages.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-14 Copy behavior in resource-managing classes
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Copying an RAII object entails copying the resource it manages, so the copying behavior of the resource determines the copying behavior of the RAII object.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-13 Use objects to manage resources
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Use RAII objects such as tr1::shared_ptr and auto_ptr to prevent resource leaks.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-12 Copy all parts of an object
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Be sure to copy all of an object’s data members and all of its base class parts.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-11 Handle self assignment in operator=
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Solve self assignment situation in operator= by comparing addresses of source and target objects, careful statement ordering, and copy-and-swap.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-10 Have assignment operators return a reference to *this
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: As title suggests.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-8 Prevent exception from leaving destructor
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: It is discouraged practice to emit exceptions from destructors.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-7 Declare destructor virtual in polymorphic base classes
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: If a class has any virtual functions (for polymorphic purpose), it should have a virtual destructor.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-6 Disallow unwanted compiler-generated functions
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Declare unwanted member functions private without implementations to disallow functionality automatically provided by compilers.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-5 What functions C++ silently generates
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Compilers may implicitly generate their own versions of default constructor, copy constructor, copy assignment operator, and destructor.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.title: Item-4 Initialize objects before they're used
item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Since C++ is fickle about initialization, some good coding style is suggested.
item.dc:creator: Nzo

item.author: daoxinzhishui@gmail.com (Nzo)
item.description: Useful tips on using const in C++.
